Posts.Title: And it keeps getting worse... Michele_T lhasamom

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2011 10:16AM Birds wrote: We are here for you!  I am 53 years old and was diagnosed in 2009.  I was at my job of 23 years and I got the news at work.  I work for surgeons.  When I told my Dr. boss (I have several different bosses), he seemed nervous and handed me a piece of paper and told me to go do the task.  He didn't even comment about my cancer until much later.  I could not even get 10 minutes of time to cry and let it sink in because I was in an office and couldn't get someone to answer the phones for me.  By the time I got home, and I live alone and have no children, I didn't even want the cry time anymore, I was just sad and frustrated.  You have nothing to be ashamed of.  Cry all you want and need to.  Call your Dr and ask for a prescription to settle your nerves a little bit.  Love and hugs!
Posts.Title: Just new-need advice jackiefoley jackiefoley

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2011 10:55AM Birds wrote: I got my surgery the week after dx.  It was offered as soon as two days, but I wanted time to get my house in order, pay bills, and let it sink in.  After surgery I was off 5 weeks, because they had to go back and do another surgery to get clear margins.  Surgery was not bad at all, lumpectomy took about 1/2 of breast and was just somewhat sore due to 4 lymph nodes being removed.  Soreness was equal to working out really hard with weights, but last longer.  Never took anything for pain.  Chemo started about a month later, just waited for port incision to heal.  6 rounds of chemo.  Worked day after first chemo, second chemo I missed chemo day, friday and the next monday.  Last four chemo's kept me off work a week and a half each time.  Then I would work a week and a half and be off a week and a half.  I did have to nap at lunch time.  Never took lunch before this happened.  Rads started about 3 weeks after last chemo.  Worked in the morning, left at noon for rad and went to bed by 8pm each night.  The two weeks after rads were the time I was the most tired.  Wish I would have taken off work then.  I did not take anything for my nerves, but I think a lot of people do.   I would have, but all pills seem to really effect me strongly, I could never even function if I took Midol!  Can you imagine how weird I was on chemo? lol.  i am doing fine now!!!!  When I was bald, I volunteered at a fun run, once i walked a 5k bald and I wish I could have been like a lot of people who kept exercising the whole time, but I didn't.  I got a bumper sticker that said Cancer, you picked the wrong bitch!  We all know that toughness doesn't determine the outcome, but I had to deal with it in this way.  I bought Cancer sucks t-shirts and wore buttons to chemo that said things like F*ck Cancer, and I had one that said My onc can beat up your onc! Cancer is not a laughing matter and I do not mean to disresect anyone with my approach to dealing with it, it's just how i do deal with it.  Martygra, you can do this!  I promise you that you can.  Hugs!

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2011 01:00PM Birds wrote: Don't be afraid to call your onc's office and get the onc on call to call you back.  They may be able to help you by telling you what to do over the phone,  If it's an allergic reaction or a side effect they are familier with.
